titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Davida Rochlin Papers LSC.2369
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Grace Diliberto, 2019.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2019 October 3.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-05 14:11:28 -0700.

physdesc.extent: (26 boxes, 6 flat boxes, 4 telescope boxes, 1 shoebox, and 12 map folders)
(311 unprocessed 3.5 inch floppy disks, 2 unprocessed 5.25 inch floppy disks, 20 unprocessed CDs)

did.abstract: Davida Rochlin is a second-generation Los Angeles architect born in October 1951. Rochlin received her Bachelor of Arts and Master's in Architecture from the University of California, Berkeley in 1973 and 1976, respectively. Rochlin gained notoriety early on in her career with research begun under the mentorship of American architect Joseph Esherick for her master's thesis on the American porch. This research on the porch has shaped Rochlin's work throughout her career, which focuses on sustainable design, ranges from residential architecture to medical and educational buildings, and encompasses exhibitions and research. The collection contains student work and records produced by Rochlin while enrolled as an architecture student in the School of Environmental Design at UC Berkeley and early career works, including apprenticeships for various architectural firms and freelance jobs. Also included are materials relating to Rochlin's professional work about the American porch, such as research, preparation for the 1983-84 exhibition The Front Porch at the Craft and Folk Art Museum (CAFAM), published magazine articles, book proposals, and exhibition materials from Rochlin's 2010 exhibition The New American Porch shown at the LA Archive Gallery. Materials created by Davida Rochlin Architecture (DRAIA), Rochlin's architecture firm, include drawings, architectural plans, research, photographs, correspondence, and other office records.
did.physloc: Portions of the collection stored off-site. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED DIGITAL/AUDIO MATERIALS: Digital/audio materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Davida Rochlin and Fred J. Marcus, 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Davida Rochlin papers (Collection 2369). Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Grace Diliberto, under the supervision of Courtney Dean in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2019. Before coming to UCLA the collection was pre-processed by an MLIS student to establish series and subseries, which were largely retained. Some subseries were combined for clarity.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Davida Rochlin is a second-generation Los Angeles architect. She was born in October 1951 to writer and historian Harriet Rochlin and architect-turned-performer and writer Fred Rochlin. She received her Bachelor of Arts in Architecture from the University of California, Berkeley (cum laude) in 1973. She went on to earn a master's degree in Architecture, also from UC Berkeley, in 1976. Rochlin gained notoriety early on in her career with research begun while working on her master's thesis on the American porch, under the mentorship of American architect Joseph Esherick. This research on the porch has shaped Rochlin's work throughout her career.

After earning her MA, Rochlin began her career at Esherick, Homsey, Dodge and Davis in San Francisco. Next, she worked briefly for Miller, Waltz and Diedrich in Atlanta. She then went on to serve as Project Planner and Architect at Rochlin and Baran (later RBB Architects) until 1986. During this time she also continued research on the American porch in Atlanta and created The Front Porch exhibition at the Craft and Folk Art Museum (CAFAM), which was part of a regional symposium and series of exhibitions titled Home Sweet Home: American Domestic Vernacular Architecture.

In 1986 Rochlin opened her own firm, Davida Rochlin Architecture (DRAIA), which operated out of the landmark Barry Building in Brentwood, California for thirty years. As of 2019, DRAIA is still active and has relocated to Santa Monica. Rochlin is a member of the American Institute of Architects (AIA), United States Green Building Council, and the International Living Future Institute. Rochlin's work exhibits a specialization in American domestic vernacular architecture and sustainability. The porch, as both a cultural icon and a passive solar design solution, shapes the theory and design behind Rochlin's architecture, which focuses on energy efficiency and renewable energy. Rochlin's work both at other firms in the early stages of her career and under DRAIA is not limited to residential and includes medical, education, and office buildings.

Some of Davida Rochlin's most well known works include the Market Street Residences (San Francisco, CA), Sea Level House (Malibu, CA), Honakai House (Big Island, HA), Rancho Girasol (Taos, NM), Elijah Wood Residence (Santa Monica, CA), Kenquest Corporate Headquarters (Beverly Hills, CA), and Leo Baeck Temple Religious School renovation (Los Angeles, CA).

Notable writing featuring DRAIA work can be found in publications including the New York Times, Los Angeles Times, Architecture, Metropolitan Home, Fine Homebuilding, LA Architect, Martha Stewart Living, artslant.com, and chanceofrain.com. Rochlin has also exhibited at the Craft and Folk Art Museum, Architecture and Design Museum, and LA Archive Gallery, all of which are located in Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection contains student work and records produced by Davida Rochlin while enrolled as an architecture student in the School of Environmental Design at UC Berkeley and early career works. Included in early career works are materials from architectural apprenticeships for architectural firms and freelance jobs. Also included are materials relating to Rochlin's professional work around the American porch, such as research, exhibition preparation for The Front Porch exhibition at the Craft and Folk Art Museum, published magazine articles, book proposals, and materials from Rochlin's 2010 exhibition, The New American Porch. Materials created by Davida Rochlin Architecture include drawings, architectural plans, research, photographs, correspondence, and other office records.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 5: Davida Rochlin Architecture (DRAIA) office records, 1984-2017
Subseries 5.2: Brochures and requests for proposals (RFPs), 1999-2010
Series 6: The New American Porch pop-up show, 2010

The materials largely retain their existing order, since they came to UCLA pre-processed into series and subseries. Some subseries were combined for clarity. These series follow Rochlin's career in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains student work by and records of Davida Rochlin while enrolled as an architecture student in the School of Environmental Design at UC Berkeley. Included are official honors letters from the dean, transcripts, and diplomas. Also included are portfolios, slides, photographs, and drawings from academic work, including design studios, such as the Chair Design Studio and San Francisco Marshall Library design; Smyth-Fernwald Child Care Center independent study and field work; and Ramona's Café Remodel for a School of Environmental Design student competition. The series also contains research, notes, drafts, and a final copy of Rochlin's master's thesis on the American porch. Additional materials include photographs and slides of porches collected during Rochlin's time at UC Berkeley, particularly while working on the thesis.

did.unittitle: San Francisco Marshall Library design studio project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plans for Architectural Field Office project and plans and photographs for Experimental School project for Architecture 101. Course description for Architecture 102B and plans for Coffeehouse project for that course. Plans and photographs for Architecture 102C Day Care Center project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Slides (photographs) of porches dated 1975-1982. Copies of three transmittals for the following projects: Redbook—the American Porch (July 1984), Redbook—Porch Sampler (1984), and Porch Sampler (undated).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file includes photographs, drawings, and slides collected during Rochlin's time at UC Berkeley. These materials relate to her research on the American Porch and are divided by region, style, or genre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains work from Davida Rochlin's early career. It includes work completed during architectural apprenticeships for various architectural firms, as well as freelance assignments. The majority of the coverage is work done for the firm Rochlin and Baran, including the Redken Research Center Laboratory (circa 1978-1986), Kaiser West LA Clinic and Hospital (1982), Northridge Pediatrics (1983), Oak Hills Medical Office Building (circa 1978-1986), and Good Samaritan Medical Office Building (circa 1978-1986).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This work is organized chronologically, with the exception of the photographs of medical projects for Rochlin and Baran, which are housed separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the American porch created during Rochlin's professional career. It includes research done in Atlanta and preparatory materials related The Front Porch exhibition at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles. Published magazine articles and book proposals on the American porch are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes photographs, slides, notes, maps, and brochures collected during Rochlin's time conducting research in Atlanta, Georgia. Coverage includes research for the Ludlow Porch Show, research for an unpublished article on the Southern porch for Brown's Guide to Georgia, and Evolution of the Georgia Porch, written by Davida Rochlin and Andrea Niles for the Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation.

did.unittitle: Maps and guidebooks of Georgia cities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains research and preparatory materials for The Front Porch exhibition organized by Rochlin at the Craft and Folk Art Museum (CAFAM) in Los Angeles, California, which ran from October 1983 to January 1984. These materials include writing, correspondence, notes, drawings, floor plans, budget and proposal, photographs and slides, reviews, advertising, newspaper publications, drafts of the catalog essay, and a copy of the exhibition catalog, Home Sweet Home: American Domestic Vernacular Architecture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains work completed by Davida Rochlin Architecture (DRAIA) with materials beginning in 1980. It includes drawings, plans, reports, photographs and correspondence. Major projects covered include the Four Porch House (also referred to at 3251 Selby), Honakai House (also referred to as the Thomas/Goff Residence), Sea Level House (also referred to as West Sea Level), Elijah Wood Residence, Market Street Residences, Kenquest Corporate Headquarters, and Rancho Girasol.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized by project and chronologically. Most projects are organized chronologically. The following projects have more significant documentation surrounding them and are, therefore, organized in subseries by project, also in chronological order: Thomas/Goff Residence, Elijah Wood Residence, Sea Level House, and Market Street Residences.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes projects completed by DRAIA between 1980 and 2010. This subseries excludes projects that have more comprehensive documentation. Materials in this subseries include photographs, negatives, slides, hand drawings and plans, and digital materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The subseries begins with an assortment of project photographs organized alphabetically by project. The rest of the subseries is arranged chronologically. Additional project photographs and oversize hand drawings are found at the end of the subseries.

Materials include photographs, site plans and renderings, documentation of specifications, permits, and requirements, and records of correspondence, contracts, and design review submissions.

did.unittitle: Elijah Wood Residence Title 24 report and structural documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials related to the design and construction of the Sea Level House (also often referred to as West Sea Level) in Malibu, California between 2003 and 2008. Materials include "before" photographs, large site plans, drawings, official documents, correspondence, notes, reports, permit applications, and hearing appeals. Much of the documentation covers structural and environmental considerations unique to the site and city requirements. This includes hydrology studies, solar energy, structural engineering and calculations, soil reports, archaeological and biological assessment, and geotechnical reports. There are also approvals for city planning and planning commission hearings, septic, fire planning, civil and structural codes, such as grading, drainage, and erosion control, and the homeowners' association. Documentation includes construction observation, process for obtaining the foundation permit, cost estimates, Title 24, and Environmental Review Board (ERB) as well.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials related to the Market Street Residences at 3198 Market Street in San Francisco, California, designed by DRAIA. Materials include site photographs, building concepts, elevations, floor plans, area survey, site and building plans, sections, and renderings. Additional materials include Green Building Permit materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains DRAIA correspondence and writing for publications including Sunset Magazine, Greenopia, Designer's West, View Magazine, Metropolitan Home Magazine, and Martha Stewart Magazine.

did.unittitle: Redken Research Center Designers West article
Greenopia "The Urban Dweller's Guide to Green Living Los Angeles" books
Series 6: The New American Porch pop-up show

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to Rochlin's 2010 exhibition, The New American Porch. Materials include an exhibition slideshow, exhibition materials, such as the artist statement and wall signage, publicity for the show, and photographs and slides from the exhibition. Media included contain the slideshow and other digital exhibition materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains unprocessed digital material, primarily CAD drawings. Included are 305 3.5 inch floppy disks, 2 5.25 inch floppy disks, and 6 CDs. Known file types include .dwg, .dxf, .kad, .pdf, .plt, .tiff, and .txt. See attached spreadsheet for a list of specific projects and additional information.
